newsitem.title: ITALY: Prodi urges Italian banks to cut lending rates.
newsitem.headline: Prodi urges Italian banks to cut lending rates.

text.p: Prime Minister Romano Prodi called on Italian banks on Thursday to cut lending rates, saying low inflation was not enough to guarantee economic recovery.

He made his appeal in a statement reacting to figures released on Thursday which showed that consumer price inflation fell in November to 2.6 percent year-on-year from 3.0 percent in October, the lowest since June 1969.
"The drop in inflation is not sufficient to guarantee the country economic recovery. We have also got to act on the cost of money," Prodi said in the statement.
He said there was a growing gulf between interest rates banks applied to some clients and those which the majority of companies, particularly smaller businesses, paid.
"The rates range from eight percent for certain loans to rates of 16 to 18 percent for similar operations," Prodi said.

"The size of the margin is excessive and completely anomalous, not only compared with other countries, but also compared with the situation in the past," he said. "It is therefore necessary that the whole range of bank interest rates should fall."
